title: New position at USC
text:
I’m thrilled to share that, as of April, I’ve joined the University of Santiago de Compostela as a Junior Lecturer (Ayudante Doctora) in the Department of English and German Philology. This is a full-time, five-year tenure-track position, and I’m excited to be part of such a vibrant academic community.
Founded in 1495, the University of Santiago de Compostela is one of Spain’s oldest and most prestigious universities, with a strong commitment to research, academic excellence, and public service. The Department of English and German Philology is known for its dynamic research environment and its wide range of teaching and research areas, including linguistics, literature, and cultural studies across English- and German-speaking contexts.

title: 8 BICLCE - Best Paper Prize
text:
I’m happy to share that I was awarded the Best Paper Prize for a Junior Researcher at the 8th Biennial International Conference on the Linguistics of Contemporary English (8 BICLCE) , held at Otto-Friedrich-Universität Bamberg, Germany (26–28 September).
My paper, Negation and the Cognitive Complexity Principle in the English Clausal Complementation System, forms part of my PhD research, supervised by Elena Seoane and Manfred Krug.
I’m very grateful for this recognition and for the opportunity to present my work at such a stimulating and welcoming conference.

title: New position at UIB
text:
Last September, I joined the University of the Balearic Islands (UIB) as a Junior Lecturer (Ayudante Doctora) in the Department of Spanish, Modern and Classical Philology.
Established in 1978, the University of the Balearic Islands is a dynamic institution with a strong international outlook and a growing research profile. The Department of Spanish, Modern and Classical Philology offers a diverse academic environment that brings together specialists in language, literature, and linguistics across several linguistic traditions.

title: Book published!
text: I just published the volume Probabilistic variability in clausal verb complementation in World Englishes (Peter Lang). The book explores finite and nonfinite clausal verb complementation in World Englishes. It provides an assessment of the influence of language contact, simplicity and transparency, geographical proximity, and evolutionary phase on this alternation. On the one hand, a quantitative analysis of GloWbE data through different statistical tests proves the effects of these factors on the choice between finite that-clauses and nonfinite -ing clauses. A number of intra-linguistic factors are also considered as potential explanatory factors. On the other hand, a detailed, manual, qualitative analysis results in the discovery of a series of new verb complementation structures available in English varieties around the world.

title: Margarita Salas 3-year posdoctoral contract
text:
I’m happy to share that I’ve been awarded a three-year Margarita Salas postdoctoral fellowship, a highly competitive grant funded by the Spanish Ministry of Universities to support early-career researchers.
During this period, I’ll be working with the SPERTUS research team, led by Prof. Ignacio Palacios Martínez, at the University of Santiago de Compostela. I look forward to developing new research directions and contributing to the team’s ongoing work in English linguistics.

title: Obtain PhD
text:
I’m delighted to share that I successfully defended my PhD dissertation this morning.
The thesis, titled Variation in the clausal complementation system in World Englishes: A corpus-based study of REGRET, was awarded the highest distinction (sobresaliente cum laude).
I am deeply grateful to my supervisors, Prof. Elena Seoane (University of Vigo) and Prof. Manfred Krug (University of Bamberg), for their guidance throughout this journey.
I would also like to sincerely thank the members of the examination board — Prof. Sarah Buschfeld (TU Dortmund), Prof. Javier Pérez-Guerra (University of Vigo), and Prof. Lourdes Loureiro-Porto (University of the Balearic Islands) — for their insightful and enriching feedback.
I’m now continuing my academic path as a postdoctoral researcher at the University of Vigo.

title: Talk at Pompeu Fabra
text:
Last week, I had the pleasure of giving an invited talk at Pompeu Fabra University in Barcelona, titled Towards Monolingualism: The Linguistic Ecology of Gibraltar.
The discussion sparked engaging reflections among both staff and students, who drew thought-provoking parallels between the sociolinguistic dynamics of Gibraltar and those of Catalonia. There was particular interest in the potential creole status of Yanito, one of Gibraltar’s vernaculars.
I’m very grateful for the warm welcome and the stimulating feedback I received — it was a real pleasure to share ideas in such a vibrant academic setting.

title: Richard M. Hogg Prize
text:
I’m honoured to share that on June 2nd I was awarded the Richard M. Hogg Prize by the International Society for the Linguistics of English (IsLE) for my paper Negation as a Predictor of Clausal Complement Choice in World Englishes.
This prize is awarded in open competition to early-career scholars — both predoctoral and postdoctoral — and includes a £500 cash award, the publication of the paper on the IsLE website, and an invitation (with financial support) to present the research at the next IsLE conference.
In addition, the paper was invited for submission to English Language and Linguistics — the journal closely associated with the Society — where it was later published as an open access article.
I’m incredibly grateful to the IsLE community for this recognition and support.

title: Descriptive Statistics
text:
Descriptive statistics help us summarize and understand the main features of a dataset. This section covers key concepts and includes R code examples.

📊 Measures of Central Tendency

Mean: The average of the data.
Median: The middle value when the data is ordered.
Mode: The most frequently occurring value.


# Sample data
data <- c(5, 8, 9, 6, 8, 7, 10, 6, 8)

# Mean
mean(data)

[1] 7.444444

# Median
median(data)

[1] 8

# Mode (custom function)
get_mode <- function(x) {
  uniqx <- unique(x)
  uniqx[which.max(tabulate(match(x, uniqx)))]
}
get_mode(data)

[1] 8




📏 Measures of Dispersion

Range: Difference between max and min values.
Variance: The average squared deviation from the mean.
Standard Deviation: Square root of the variance.


# Range
range(data)

[1]  5 10

diff(range(data))  # Range as a single number

[1] 5

# Variance
var(data)

[1] 2.527778

# Standard Deviation
sd(data)

[1] 1.589899




📈 Data Visualization
Visual representations are essential for understanding the distribution of data.

# Histogram
hist(data, main = "Histogram of Data", col = "skyblue", border = "white")





# Boxplot
boxplot(data, main = "Boxplot of Data", col = "lightgreen")





# Bar plot for frequency
barplot(table(data), main = "Bar Plot of Frequencies", col = "lightcoral")







✅ Summary
Descriptive statistics give you a first understanding of your data. You can use these techniques and R code snippets to quickly explore any dataset before moving on to more complex analysis.
